newsArray.title: Crows‚Äô top-10 draft pick takes personal leave
newsArray.description: Former No.6 draft pick Fischer McAsey isn‚Äôt expected to start pre-season until after Christmas after Adelaide granted him personal leave.
newsArray.content: The Crows first to four-year players will begin pre-season on Monday, with boom recruit Izak Rankine expected to be at West Lakes as he recovers from shoulder surgery. Players who took part in the SANFL finals campaign have been given an extra week and will start their pre-season campaigns next Monday. McAsey was in that group but on the eve of pre-season the Crows announced that the 21-year-old had been granted personal leave. Crows Head of Football Adam Kelly said the club was understanding of McAsey‚Äôs circumstances and he was not expected to return until after the Christmas break.‚ÄúWe are fully supportive of Fischer taking personal leave and we will give him the time and space that he requires,‚Äù Kelly said.‚ÄúWe will remain in regular communication with him, as well as his management, to ensure he has ongoing support while away from the club.‚ÄúAs always, the welfare of our people is the top priority and we ask that Fischer‚Äôs privacy be respected during this period.‚ÄùWhen he was selected with the sixth pick of the 2019 draft, McAsey was at the time the Crows‚Äô highest ever draft pick. He played 10 games in his debut season, but hasn‚Äôt played at AFL level since. In the 2021 pre-season his father, Chris, had a major health scare while McAsey was back home in Melbourne for the first time in months due to coronavirus travel limitations. He signed a two-year contract extension in April 2021 after speculation that he would look for a move back to Victoria. He played 18 SANFL games last season and finished eighth in the Crows‚Äô state-league best-and-fairest in 2021.But McAsey suffered another setback when he sustained a stress fracture in his femur in December 2021, which sidelined him for six weeks. When he returned via the SANFL he was shifted forward in an attempt by the Crows for him to find some form. He then revealed to TV crews that he had been in discussions about a move back to Melbourne. But nothing eventuated during the trade period and Crows list manager Justin Reid told News Corp in September that a full pre-season would do McAsey the world of good. ‚ÄúI guess being a high draft pick there is also high expectations, but we feel like we have the program around Fischer and his off-season and pre-season will dictate the season he has next year,‚Äù he said. But for the third year in a row McAsey will have an interrupted pre-season, ahead of the final year of his contract.

newsArray.content: The French national team was subjected to a new shock after the French national team captain, Karim Benzema, was excluded from the list of the national team participating in the World Cup, to join the list of absent players, namely Paul Pogba, Prisnel Kimpembe, N‚ÄôGolo Kante and Christopher Nkunku, and this came because the player was injured during the French national team‚Äôs training. Karim Benzema published the news of his exclusion from the 2022 World Cup with an impressive message in his official account on the ‚ÄúInstagram‚Äù website, after the injury he sustained during the training of the Rooster Battalion: ‚ÄúIn my life I have never given up, but tonight I have to think about the team as I always do, so I was told To leave my place for someone who can help the national team achieve a great achievement in the World Cup .. Thank you all for the messages of support.‚Äù The French Football Federation confirmed that player Karim Benzema underwent MRI medical examinations in a hospital in Doha, which proved that Benzema had a muscle tear in the femoral rectum. The French national team striker will need a recovery period of at least 3 weeks, to become outside the accounts of coach Didier Deschamps in the World Cup, after he had been absent from Real Madrid for a while during the current season, due to injury and muscle fatigue as well. It is noteworthy that Karim Benzema did not participate in the previous edition of the World Cup with the French national team, which was crowned with the title led by its young star Kylian Mbappe, after defeating the Croatian national team in the final match. newsArray.title: Farcical FIFA speech sucks focus away from football
newsArray.description: So much for focusing on the football.
newsArray.content: In his wild address to the world‚Äôs media to open football‚Äôs showpiece event, FIFA president Gianni Infantino did little ‚Äì if anything ‚Äì to dispel the concerns that have plagued the Qatar tournament or enhance the excitement for the on-pitch action at this World Cup.If anything, he simply cemented the view that the world‚Äôs governing body for football is stuck in the dark ages, with its head in the sand and boasting little enthusiasm to ever change.For months ‚Äì years, even ‚Äì Infantino and FIFA have hoped that the issues surrounding their controversial decision to award the World Cup to Qatar would dissipate.That the football would take over and steal the spotlight.But with a remarkable speech that will go down in history, largely for reasons other than those Infantino intended, he ensured that whatever happens in the next six weeks, the on-field results will always be secondary when this World Cup is remembered.Perhaps that was always going to be the case.Two weeks ago, when Infantino and secretary general Fatma Samoura sent a formal letter to the football federations of all competing nations urging them to ‚Äúfocus on the football‚Äù, in a desperate bid to drive the narrative away from the social and human rights issues which have plagued Qatar‚Äôs 12-year build up to this tournament.The message ‚Äì a more long-winded version of ‚Äòshut up and dribble‚Äô ‚Äì went down like a lead balloon to many of the 32 countries who will fight for the priceless gold trophy over the coming six weeks.The likes of the USA, who unveiled a rainbow-themed logo at their training centre, and Denmark, through coach Kasper Hjulmand who declared the Danes ‚Äòwill not be silenced‚Äô on human rights issues, clearly took little notice of it.And it seems neither did Infantino.Because, barely 24 hours out from the game between the host nation and Ecuador, Infantino stole back the spotlight for himself and opened FIFA up for ridicule once more.It was the height of hypocrisy from a man who himself accused Western critics of double standards over their attacks on Qatar.‚ÄúWe are told to make many lessons from some Europeans, from the western world,‚Äù Infantino said.‚ÄúI think for what we Europeans have been doing for 3,000 years around the world, we should be apologising for the next 3,000 years before starting to give moral lessons to people.‚ÄùInfantino‚Äôs tone was one of strict school teacher, scolding the media. But he is treading down a path of Sepp Blatterism; where he forgets his role and thinks he can solve the world‚Äôs geopolitical and cultural problems.At least that‚Äôs one conclusion to draw from his farcical suggestion of pitching North Korea as a Women‚Äôs World Cup host ‚Äì alongside South Korea.‚ÄúFootball brings people together. If we want to organise an event in North Korea, I actually went to North Korea some years ago to ask if they were ready to host part of a Women‚Äôs World Cup with South Korea,‚Äù he added.‚ÄúI was not successful, obviously. But I‚Äôm still convinced‚Ä¶ This particular World Cup will help to open the eyes of the world.‚ÄùInfantino, who is confirmed to be running unopposed for the FIFA presidency again next year, implored critics to leave Qatar alone and to direct all fury at him. And he may get his wish over the next 24 hours.‚ÄúIf you want to criticise someone, criticise me, I am here, crucify me. Don‚Äôt criticise Qatar. Criticise FIFA, criticise me,‚Äù he said.And so, after an incredible performance, Infantino finished his 55-minute rant perhaps the way he should‚Äôve started it.‚ÄúNow, onto the World Cup‚Ä¶‚Äù

newsArray.title: First test for Bombers‚Äô punishing new training standards
newsArray.description: Essendon is adamant its players have already laid the groundwork for a gruelling summer after the club‚Äôs admission it needed a ‚Äúdemanding‚Äù pre-season following a year with too many unfit players.
newsArray.content: The Bombers‚Äô young players will return to the Hangar on Monday to start their pre-Christmas block of training after an off-season of profound change at the club.New coach Brad Scott has promised a methodical build instead of a quick fix and has a significantly beefed-up development team to maximise the club‚Äôs exciting young list.Football boss Josh Mahoney told the Herald Sun on Sunday that team lacked for nothing, headed by Cam Roberts and including Michael Hurley, Brent Stanton, Leigh Tudor, VFLW coach Travis Cloke and AFLW coach Natalie Wood.It means Essendon will give its core group of 18-25 year olds every chance to make the kind of dramatic improvement best-and-fairest winner Peter Wright achieved in the past two seasons.But first the Bombers must reach elite fitness after president David Barham said the club‚Äôs review stated a need to ‚Äúdrive higher training standards and to build a better fitness base‚Äù with a ‚Äúdemanding pre-season‚Äù that improved fitness across the board.Club legend Adam Ramanauskas called out Jake Stringer for his poor work rate after he returned from injury mid-season looking unfit.SCBBL PROMOThe Bombers group were unfairly criticised for heading overseas for a post-season football trip, and Mahoney said months of training through the off-season had them ready to go.‚ÄúI think across the competition you can see there are players itching to get back into pre-season. Our players are no different. They have been getting together in reasonable size groups and working hard together. From what we have seen already for guys coming through the Hangar, they are in good shape and they will be able to hit the ground running tomorrow,‚Äù Mahoney said.‚ÄúThat trip was a long time ago now, so they have had that time, and now had a solid block of six to eight weeks of training with an off-season program. There is not much time, only four weeks before the Christmas break so every training session is important for us and the players are really clear that is our mindset going into this pre-season.‚ÄùJye Caldwell had AC joint surgery post-season but will join in full training before Christmas, with James Stewart (foot) and Tex Wanganeen (navicular) the only two other players who will not be at full pace immediately upon their return.Dyson Heppell could give up the captaincy after signing on again for another season but Mahoney said the club hadn‚Äôt worked through that process.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably something we will look at through the pre-season period. We haven‚Äôt had any discussions with Dyson about it. He is our captain and we have a good group of players around him that help out, but it will bea focus for us across our playing group to improve our leadership capabilities, and it‚Äôs not just going to fall on our captain.‚ÄùMahoney said new coach Scott would work on his game style across summer to marry it with the list‚Äôs strengths, but was aware of the need to prioritise contest work and the club‚Äôs defence.‚ÄúBrad is taking time to work out our list, what our strengths are as a team and it will evolve over the pre-season,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe think when we do play offensively we are naturally a very effective team going forward. ‚ÄúWe had some work to do defensively, but we think a balanced approach and improving around the contest is going to be important for us and making sure we still have the flair in offence, but also strengthening up our defence.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Latham‚Äôs anger over Zelic‚Äôs World Cup claim
newsArray.description: Mark Latham has taken an extraordinary, unprovoked swipe at Australian football commentator Lucy Zelic hours before the World Cup opening ceremony.
newsArray.content: The former SBS TV host on Sunday revealed her reservations about the Qatar World Cup, an event that has become one of the most divisive sporting events in recent memory.The popular football analyst posted on Twitter her discomfort at celebrating the event, which has been largely overshadowed by widespread protests and condemnation of the host nation‚Äôs human rights abuses. The former Labor MP turned One Nation MLC responded by suggesting Zelic should not be politicising the World Cup. The horse has already bolted ‚Äî long ago.The Socceroos have stuck their necks out in Qatar after being the first national team to make a unanimous statement of condemnation of the World Cup host earlier this year.With the World Cup opening ceremony beginning on Monday morning AEDT and with the Socceroos just days away from their 2022 World Cup opener against France on November 23 at 6am AEDT ‚Äî the debate about saying ‚ÄòNup to the Cup‚Äô is raging. Watch the world‚Äôs best footballers every week with beIN SPORTS on Kayo. LIVE coverage from Bundesliga, Ligue 1, Serie A, Carabao Cup, EFL & SPFL. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now >Zelic says it ‚Äúwould feel weird to act like a cheerleader‚Äù as the world‚Äôs most watched sporting event kicks off. ‚ÄúOn the eve of the FIFA World Cup I wanted to wish all the competing nations + administrators great success, but it‚Äôs been such an unsettling build-up to this tournament, which has been plagued by unnecessary tragedy + controversy that it would feel weird to act like a cheerleader,‚Äù she wrote on Twitter.‚ÄúWhen your sport is built on the fundamental belief that every nation, player, man, woman or child is welcome to participate in it - your organisation, and who you entrust to represent those beliefs, damn-well better reflect that. ‚ÄúSo, whilst I‚Äôll still watch my beloved teams and admire the football, I‚Äôll also be thinking of the families who lost loved ones and ask why it had to come to this. @FIFAcom we want it to be about the football but YOU choose to make it about everything else.‚ÄùHer comment referenced the fact Qatar‚Äôs $A470 billion construction extravaganza for the tournament came at the cost of an estimated 6500 construction workers‚Äô lives.Qatar was controversially awarded the rights to host the biggest sporting event on the planet in 2010 despite a lack of facilities and the prospect of playing the tournament in hot desert conditions. That is just the tip of the iceberg.Homosexuality is also illegal in Qatar and Muslims found breaking the strict Islamic law can face the death penalty. Latham responded to Zelic‚Äôs tweet by saying: ‚ÄúGet a grip, it‚Äôs just a game of soccer‚Äù.He also responded to one of her tweets by writing: ‚ÄúIf you want to turn soccer into politics, at least have the courage to put your name on a ballot paper‚Äù. FIFA Sweep No-oddsFootball icon David Beckham has been repeatedly criticised this month over his mega-rich deal as an ambassador for the host nation and the tournament. The former England and Manchester United star has signed a 10-year deal worth a reported $A266 million to promote the World Cup and its host nation Qatar.Socceroos great Craig Foster this week slammed Beckham over the Arab nation‚Äôs discrimination against gay people and women, as well as its human rights record.‚ÄúNot saying anything about the criminalisation of the LGBTI community in Qatar is absolutely horrendous,‚Äù Foster said.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been called on by various people in the UK to change his stance. I hope he does.‚ÄúHis incredible brand known all around the world... he actually has an opportunity to try and create significant impact and even change there in Qatar, so I hope he uses it.‚ÄùThe Socceroos also earned plenty of praise from around the world for its powerful statement in the lead up to the tournament.Sixteen players read lines from a collective statement calling for an ‚Äúeffective remedy‚Äù to Qatar‚Äôs human rights issues.‚ÄúAddressing these issues is not easy. And we do not have all the answers,‚Äù the Australian players said.‚ÄúWe stand with FIFPro, the Building and Wood Workers International, and the International Trade Union Confederation, seeking to embed reforms and establish a lasting legacy in Qatar. This must include establishing a migrant resource centre, effective remedy for those who have been denied their rights, and the decriminalisation of all same-sex relationships.‚ÄúThese are the basic rights that should be afforded to all and will ensure continued progress in Qatar ‚Ä¶ [and] a legacy that goes well beyond the final whistle of the 2022 FIFA World Cup.‚Äù

newsArray.content: Toga : FIFA‚Äôs 22nd FIFA World Cup kicks off with a bang today in Qatar. The opening match will be held at 9.30 pm and the teams of Qatar and Ecuador will face each other. The 22nd edition of the biennial FIFA World Cup kicks off in Qatar today. With this, Qatar becomes the first Middle Eastern country to host the World Cup football series for the first time in history. 32 teams are participating in this football festival which will be held till December 18. These are divided into 4 categories. There are 4 teams in each division. Group ‚ÄòA‚Äô includes Qatar, Ecuador, Senegal and Netherlands. England, Iran, USA and Wales are in Group ‚ÄòB‚Äô and Argentina, Saudi Arabia, Mexico and Poland are in Group ‚ÄòC‚Äô and France, Australia, Denmark and Tunisia are in Group D and Spain and Costa are in Group E. Teams from Riga, Germany and Japan are also placed. Belgium, Canada, Morocco and Croatia are in Group F, Brazil, Serbia, Switzerland and Cameroon are in Group G and Portugal, Ghana, Uruguay and South Korea are in Group H. At the end of the league round, the top two teams in each division will advance to the knockout round. The knockout round matches will be played on 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th and 7th December, quarter finals on 9th, 10th and 11th and semi finals on 14th and 15th. The title decider will be played on December 18 at the 80,000-capacity Lusail Stadium. 64 matches will be played in the football festival to entertain millions of fans. Brazil, who has won the title of champion 5 times, Germany, who has won the title 4 times, Argentina, France, Uruguay, who have won the title 2 times each, and England and Spain, who have held the trophy once each, are going to jump into the field to establish their dominance. With star players like Cristiano Ronaldo, Lionel Messi, Neymar, Lewandowski, Karel Bale, Romelu Lukaku, Modric, Christian Eriksen, Hurricane, Karine Benzema, Kylian Mbappe, Germany‚Äôs 17-year-old Eusuba Mukoko, Brazil‚Äôs Vinicius Junior, Portugal‚Äôs Joao Felix, Spain‚Äôs Ansufati, Ferran Torres The football talent of the young players is waiting to entertain the fans. As many as 12 lakh fans are expected to visit Qatar to watch the match. Hostels, floating hotels and special tents in the desert have been arranged for them. Qatar has spent about US$220 billion on the month-long football festival. A large amount of this has been used for infrastructure. The team that wins the World Cup football series will get a prize of Rs 342 crore in Indian value. The second place team will be awarded Rs 244 crore, while the third and fourth place teams will be awarded Rs 219 crore and Rs 203 crore respectively. Similarly, the 4 teams that will be eliminated in the quarter-finals will be awarded Rs.138 crore each, the 8 teams that will be eliminated in the second round of knock-out games will be awarded Rs.105 crore each, and the 16 teams that will be eliminated in the league round will be awarded Rs.73 crore each. The total prize money for this year‚Äôs World Cup series is Rs. 3,586 crores. This is an additional amount of Rs 328 crore over the previous period. In the 2018 World Cup football series held in Russia, Rs.3,258 crore was given as prize money. The opening ceremony of the football festival will be held at 7.30 PM IST tonight at Albed Stadium. Jungkook, a famous singer from South Korea, will perform at the ceremony. Following this, in the first match at 9.30 pm, the teams of Qatar and Ecuador will clash. Qatar, ranked 50th, qualified directly for the World Cup as the host nation. Ecuador ranks 44th in the team rankings. Sports18 is telecasting all the matches of this series live.

newsArray.title: ‚ÄòDumfounded‚Äô: Ref slammed for weak call on freak hit
newsArray.description: Kangaroos forward Angus Crichton has apologised to the family of Chanel Harris-Tavita and the entire Samoan community for the tackle that prematurely ended the hooker‚Äôs night in the World Cup final.
newsArray.content: Crichton was sin-binned and placed on report after his forearm contacted Harris-Tavita ‚Äî Samoan coach Matt Parish claimed he should have been sent off - but spoke with genuine remorse after the game as one of the greatest moments of his career was tainted by an unfortunate accident.Crichton also revealed he was planning to travel to Amsterdam with Harris-Tavita and others after the final.‚ÄúFirst and foremost I was worried about him,‚Äù Crichton said.‚ÄúHe is a great player and I am actually meant to be traveling with him after this. There is no bad blood between me and Chanel.‚ÄúWe talked after the game and we know there is all love there. It was honestly a genuine freak accident. ‚ÄúI never want anyone to get injured on the field like that, especially knockouts. Two of my great mates in Jackie Friend and Boyd Cordner, it has ruined their careers. ‚ÄúSo I never want to injure anyone. That was not my intention at all. So anyone I have upset, anyone in his family, anyone in the Samoan community that I have upset, I am genuinely sorry for that because it was not my intention.‚ÄúI am looking forward to hanging out with him. I want to get the message across and I want to let his family know that I am genuinely sorry, I want to let the Samoan community know that there was no malice in it.‚ÄùParish was ropable that Crichton was allowed to return to the action, taking aim at referee Ashley Klein.‚ÄúFive minutes into the second half our hooker gets elbowed in the head and gets carted off,‚Äù Parish said.‚ÄúThe referee makes a weak decision and puts him in the bin. Dumfounded.‚ÄùAsked whether it was a poor decision, Parish said: ‚ÄúAn elbow to the head and the hooker gets taken out of the game. What do you think.‚ÄùIf Crichton is charged by the match review committee, he is likely to miss the start of next for the Sydney Roosters. Samoan captain Junior Paulo was comfortable with the decision.‚ÄúKnowing Angus Crichton, I have been playing [against] him for a while now, it is probably not in his game,‚Äù Paulo said.‚ÄúSo it is what it is.‚ÄùTold of Parish‚Äôs comments, Australian coach Mal Meninga said:‚ÄúMy view is that he should have stayed on the field, that‚Äôs just silly‚Äù. Crichton was thankful to Paulo for the support.‚ÄúObviously I have known Junior a long time and I am great mates with Junior,‚Äù Crichton said.‚ÄúIt is all love between me and Chanel.He knows whenever I play football, I don‚Äôt try to injure anyone or try to hurt anyone. I know I am a good person.‚ÄúI play the game the way the game is meant to be played.‚ÄùDespite his troubles in the final, Crichton emerged from the World Cup with his reputation enhanced after playing a prominent role for the Kangaroos throughout the tournament.‚ÄúIt is amazing,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúTo be over on the other side of the world in front of my mum and dad, it was an amazing experience.‚ÄúI loved every moment for sure. It has been a huge honour to be able to represent Australia. To play under Mal (Meninga) has given me a lot of confidence.‚ÄúObviously today wasn‚Äôt the game that I planned on playing but it was the game that occurred and I am just happy we came away with the win.‚ÄúIt was a great moment in my career.‚Äù

newsArray.description: France‚Äôs hopes of successfully defending the World Cup were dealt a huge blow on Sunday morning AEDT as Ballon d‚ÄôOr winner Karim Benzema was ruled out of the tournament in Qatar with an injured left thigh.
newsArray.content: The 34-year-old Real Madrid striker had been struggling with the injury for some time and had played less than half an hour of football in his club‚Äôs last six games before the World Cup.On Saturday, he took part in full training for the first time since the World Cup holders gathered last week ahead of the tournament.Photos captured the moment Benzema was seen struggling during the session.He was forced to withdraw from the session at the home stadium of Qatari champions Al Sadd with the injury and was taken for tests.The French Football Federation (FFF) later said in a statement that the injury ‚Äúwill require a recovery period of three weeks‚Äù, ruling out any prospect of him being fully fit for the tournament which finishes on December 18.‚ÄúI am extremely sad for Karim, for whom this World Cup was a major objective,‚Äù France coach Didier Deschamps was quoted as saying in the FFF statement.‚ÄúDespite this new blow for the France team I have full faith in my squad. We will do all we can to rise to the huge challenge that awaits us.‚Äù Confirming his withdrawal, Benzema stated: ‚ÄúIn my life I have never given up, but tonight I have to think about the team as I have always done.‚ÄúSo reason tells me to leave my place to someone who can help our squad have a good World Cup.‚ÄúThank you for all your messages of support.‚ÄùIt is a hammer blow for the team and the nation of 68 million people. The 36-year-old Olivier Giroud is set to benefit from Benzema‚Äôs absence by coming into the France attack alongside Kylian Mbappe and Antoine Griezmann.However, under FIFA rules Deschamps can still call up a replacement for an injured player until Monday, on the eve of their first game.France begin their defence of the trophy on Tuesday, when they take on Australia in Al Wakrah.They will also play Denmark and Tunisia in Group D as they aim to become the first team since Brazil in 1962 to retain the World Cup.Benzema‚Äôs injury is a major blow for Deschamps, whose preparations for the tournament had already been hampered by fitness problems.France have come to Qatar without the key duo of Paul Pogba and N‚ÄôGolo Kante, their starting midfield pairing from the successful 2018 World Cup campaign, who were both ruled out due to injury before Deschamps named his squad.Back-up goalkeeper Mike Maignan and centre-back Presnel Kimpembe also withdrew before RB Leipzig forward Christopher Nkunku had to pull out after suffering a knee injury in France‚Äôs final training session before departing for Qatar.Nkunku was replaced in the squad by Eintracht Frankfurt forward Randal Kolo Muani.Manchester United defender Raphael Varane has also been struggling to prove his fitness since coming off in tears with a leg injury in a game against Chelsea on October 22.Benzema, who will turn 35 next month, had targeted the World Cup to cap off a remarkable career renaissance.He won the Ballon d‚ÄôOr after scoring 44 goals in 46 games for Real Madrid last season as the Spanish club won the Champions League and La Liga.Benzema had previously been frozen out of the France team for five-and-a-half years because of his involvement in a blackmail scandal over a sex tape involving his former teammate Mathieu Valbuena.That saw him miss France‚Äôs victorious 2018 World Cup campaign and led to him being handed a one-year suspended prison sentence as well as a fine of 75,000 euros.On winning the Ballon d‚ÄôOr he said: ‚ÄúThere are things that are still left to be done. I hope to be in the squad for Qatar, to go to the World Cup and do everything to win it.‚Äù

Related Highlights, key plays and photos from BYU‚Äôs 52-26 win over Utah Tech Here are three takeaways from the Cougars‚Äô sixth win of the season, which clinched bowl eligibility for them.It wasn‚Äôt always clean, but it was enough Utah Tech spent a good portion of the first half with a lead before BYU went ahead for good with just over five minutes until halftime. Even then, it was a one-score game midway through the third quarter.But the Cougars scored 31 straight points at one point to finally put the game away, and they relied on their passing game to fuel their offense until late in the second half, when their rush attack started putting up yards.BYU finished with 676 yards of total offense, including a career-best 456 passing yards from Jaren Hall. Hall, who went over 3,000 passing yards on the season with Saturday‚Äôs effort, accounted for six total touchdowns ‚Äî five passing and one rushing ‚Äî to go with one interception.¬† You heard it here! Jaren Hall is a superhero ü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è#GoCougs | #BYUFOOTBALL pic.twitter.com/a4HN6qtpTP‚Äî BYU Sports Nation (@BYUSportsNation) November 20, 2022 His main target was Keanu Hill, who had six receptions for 137 yards and a career-high three TD receptions, all in the first half.Chris Brooks had 102 rushing yards on Senior Day, with all but 1 yard coming in the second half.The Cougars were sloppy at times ‚Äî BYU finished with 11 penalties for 132 yards, and that included four penalties for 55 yards on a 55-yard touchdown drive in the third quarter.BYU also didn‚Äôt get too many of its younger players on offense, such as quarterback Jacob Conover, some valuable reps, as the team was trying to find a rhythm deep into the second half.Still, the effort was enough to earn a win ‚Äî something not to take for granted in an up-and-down season. Spenser Heaps, Deseret News 19 of 19 BYU‚Äôs defense shut things down after a wobbly first half The halftime stats for Utah Tech looked scary for the BYU defense: The Trailblazers had 277 yards of total offense in the first two quarters, including 208 passing yards from Victor Gabalis.Utah Tech had benefited from long passes of 54 yards and 80 yards (a touchdown) when the Cougars‚Äô secondary suffered breakdowns in coverage.That all led to a 28-20 game, with BYU leading, when the two teams went into the half. Utah Tech led by six three different times in the first half.In the second half, though, the Cougars finally put the clamps on a high-scoring Utah Tech offense that helped the Trailblazers enter Provo on a three-game winning streak.BYU forced Utah Tech to punt on six straight possessions in the second half ‚Äî that included four three-and-outs ‚Äî before the Trailblazers scored a late touchdown with the game well in hand. .@kalanifsitake has to say some goodbyes üò•#GoCougs | #BYUFOOTBALL pic.twitter.com/MX1iCWnerl‚Äî BYU Sports Nation (@BYUSportsNation) November 20, 2022 There are things to fix for sure: Utah Tech had 420 yards of total offense, including 350 yards passing from Gabalis, who finished with three touchdowns and one interception.The Cougars gave up two 100-yard receivers ‚Äî Deven Osborne had three catches for 138 yards and a touchdown, while Joey Hobert added 11 receptions for 100 yards and two scores.BYU also had another game in which it failed to register a sack, and the Cougars struggled getting pressure on the QB for too much of the day.BYU allowed Utah Tech to convert just 4 of 16 third downs, though, and gave up just 3.8 yards per carry.After a scary first half, the second half at least gave some hope for BYU‚Äôs final two games of the season. BYU is bowl eligible It was closer than expected for a good portion of the game, but BYU got to bowl eligibility with its sixth win of the season and second straight.Getting bowl eligible didn‚Äôt seem like a certainty during the program‚Äôs four-game losing streak in October.The extra practices afforded for bowl prep will be beneficial for the Cougars as they prepare to join the Big 12 Conference next season.BYU will wrap up the regular season with a game at the Pac-12‚Äôs Stanford, and going into the day, the Cougars were a slight favorite for that matchup, according to ESPN‚Äôs Football Power Index.

newsArray.title: Getting nasty: Which club is leaking to headquarters?
newsArray.description: NRL clubs are almost back to being normal.
newsArray.content: The feeling of solidarity in the funding dispute with the NRL is fast disappearing.Half the clubs now want to accept the NRL‚Äôs latest offer, the other half don‚Äôt.It‚Äôs getting nasty behind the scenes.One CEO, who shall remain nameless, has been accused of sharing sensitive information from chief executive phone hook-ups straight to NRL headquarters.This guy won‚Äôt have too many mates at the next CEO‚Äôs conference. That can be assured.If it‚Äôs true it‚Äôs a low act and even Super League-esque.The split in the ranks is just what the NRL wanted.The solid clubs want to look after their major asset ‚Äî the players ‚Äî and hold off on agreement until the RLPA deal for player wages is finalised.At least we know it‚Äôs back to business as usual. That the unity could never last.Not in rugby league. It‚Äôs the game that lives off bitter rivalries and hostilities. SAINT, SINNER, SHOOSH: LOW BLOW FOR GALLENIn a major snub, old warhorse Paul Gallen has been relegated from main event status for his farewell fight against Justin Hodges on Wednesday night.It is a huge shock and could be considered disrespectful to the 41-year-old sporting warrior who has regularly dragged in big pay-per-view audiences for promoters No Limit and Foxtel‚Äôs Main Event.In fairness Gallen‚Äôs form has been on the decline for two years and the fight with Hodges, whom he fought not so long ago, lacks the appeal of some of his bigger shows.Age has finally caught up with one of Australia‚Äôs toughest ever sports stars.Instead the highly regarded world middleweight contender Michael Zerafa has been given the main billing on Wednesday night at Darling Harbour‚Äôs International convention centre.It marks an incredible turnaround for Zerafa, who infamously pulled out of his much-hyped grudge match against Tim Tszyu in July last year.So low were the Melburnians‚Äô stocks at the time, there was even talk he would never fight on television in Australia again.But with a new team and talk of a potential world title shot against Gennady Golovkin on the horizon, Zerafa risks it all against Sydney-based Italian Danilo Creati.It will be a huge night of boxing with another rugby league star on debut as Gallen calls it a day.As first reported by this column, France bound ex-Rooster Siua Sio Taukehio has been confirmed to make his boxing debut against former South Sydney, Cowboys and Storm enforcer Jaiman Lowe.Securing the Tongan international a fight had been a challenge for promoters due the timing around the rugby league world Cup.South Sydney Rabbitohs forward Daniel Suluka-Fifita will also make his professional boxing debut on the card. Suluka-Fifita has been training under the watchful eye legendary trainer of Johnny Lewis for the past eight weeks having started boxing training at Redfern PCYC as a 13 year-old.* * * * * SAINTFooty legend Ian Walsh came from the tiny country town of Eugowra that has been wiped out in the floods. Walsh‚Äôs daughter Donna still lives in the area. Donna is assisting in the huge recovery operation and has appealed to NRL clubs to help out. Not with money but with manpower. ‚ÄúEugowra put dad on the map as a rugby league player,‚Äù Donna said, ‚ÄúI know he‚Äôd want me to be reaching out to the game when the town is suffering like it is.‚Äù Donna has even organised for Dominos to supply free pizzas for the clean-up operation. All she needs now is some players. Donna can be contacted on 0409 743 682 if you‚Äôd like to help out.SINNERWe all love Victor Radley, even those who dislike the Roosters. He‚Äôs a great character and a tough old-school footy player. However there comes a time when we all need to grow up and walk away from a looming incident and/or violence, even when provoked. It‚Äôs time for him to start behaving like a professional athlete.SHOOSHWhich big-name NRL star is talking to a rival Sydney club about the possibility of him quitting his team for an immediate switch. It is potentially a monster story.SPOTTEDCommission chairman Peter V‚Äôlandys and NRL boss Andrew Abdo entering the North Sydney headquarters of the independent always ‚Äì or at least sometimes ‚Äì Nine Entertainment, presumably for a meeting with CEO Mike Sneesby and senior SMH editorial executives last week.SPOTTEDIt can be tough work for a boxer preparing to fight for a world title. Tim Tszyu has moved his training camp to Thailand ahead of the January super fight against Jermell Charlo. He takes a break every now and then to go jetskiing.SPOTTEDThe great Ken Arthurson has understandably been struggling since the recent passing of his lovely wife, Barbara. It helps that there are good people like Tom Trbojevic around. Turbo picked up the phone last week to ring and check in on the legendary old Manly supremo. Their chat has given Arko an enormous lift.SPOTTEDAllianz Stadium maintenance staff replacing 30 seats that were stomped on and smashed by fans at the Sydney FC v Wanderers derby last weekend. Sydney FC will be getting the repair bill in the mail next week. SPOTTEDIt doesn‚Äôt always pay to have India or Pakistan in big cricket finals in Australia. This is an empty bar at the MCG last Sunday night in the 14th over of the game. Their fans rarely drink at the cricket. It costs the caterers big time. If the Aussies were playing, they‚Äôd be lining up six-deep. THE POLITICIAN, HONEY KING PRAWNS AND NOT-SO-SECRET MEETINGNo other NRL club can leak sensitive information like the Canterbury Bulldogs.You‚Äôll remember last November Eels hooker Reed Mahoney was having a private dinner in the club‚Äôs Chinese restaurant with Gus Gould and Trent Barrett. Contract talks over honey king prawns and Mongolian lamb. A picture was sent straight to The Daily Telegraph.You‚Äôve got to wonder why they met in such a public space.Then there was the photo of Billy Kikau in a Bulldogs shirt at Belmore with Gus and Baz being leaked last year while he was still at the Penrith Panthers. Highly embarrassing for Kikau, who copped a hard time from his fans.An employee, who took a frame from security CCTV and circulated it on social media, was sacked.Then July this year. Cameron Ciraldo and his manager George Mimis had a secret lunch with Bulldogs sponsor Craig Laundy to discuss the coaching job. Footage was leaked straight to Channel 9. This week, same again. Hotel billionaire Arthur Laundy signed up for a new five-year sponsorship deal to match the length of Ciraldo‚Äôs coaching contract.It‚Äôs worth $1 million a year or $1.2 million if they make the finals.A good positive story about a rock-solid businessman who signed up when the club was at its lowest but is now committing long term.The plan was to make a major announcement this week to ensure Laundy got maximum exposure.Turns out Craig Laundy had photos taken on his phone at the official signing. He shared them with Gould, Ciraldo and other mates on Wednesday night. His pictures then hit social media.To be fully transparent, your columnist is writing this with a certain amount of disappointment.We were going to reveal the $5 million sponsorship deal two weeks ago. Chairman John Khoury and CEO Aaron Warburton asked us to hold off. We made an agreement. We would break the story this week before their official announcement.Craig Laundy, a former Liberal federal minister, is like all politicians. They leak like a sieve.The Daily Telegraph NRL Podcast ‚Äì PlaylistBOO & BALI A TRIBUTE TO FIFITARecently retired Sharks big man Andrew Fifita has found himself in a little bit of froth and bubble while holidaying in Bali.But before you jump to conclusions, the froth and bubble was courtesy of a barista who amazed the 2016 premiership hero, garnishing his brew with a recent tribute cartoon, done by Telegraph sports sketcher Boo Bailey.The copying process is a specialty of the house at Coffee Cartel and had a surprised Fifita joking: ‚ÄúI got squeezed out of the Sharks cap, but made it into this one.‚ÄùSYDNEY FC SIGN UP 11-YEAR-OLD TWINSSydney FC have signed their youngest ever players ‚Äì 11-year-old identical twin brothers.Jacob and Benjamin Zaidel have joined the club‚Äôs junior academy alongside some of the country‚Äôs most outstanding soccer prospects.It is an exciting story on the eve of the World Cup that local clubs are now following the lead of global giants in Europe and South America by recognising kids at such a young age.‚ÄúThey live and breathe the game,‚Äù says their dad Dani. ‚ÄúWho knows what the future holds ‚Äì as long as they keep enjoying it.‚ÄùInterestingly there are rules in the NRL that prevent clubs from signing players before they turn 15.The boys have been identified by Kelly Cross, Sydney FC‚Äôs youth technical director, who has a long and proud history of nurturing the best talent in Australian soccer.Kelly is a former head of football at Westfield Sports High who coached current Socceroos Aaron Mooy and Andrew Redmayne, as well as Harry Kewell, Alex Brosque and Jason Culina.‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been monitoring Ben and Jacob for a period of time and it became clear that they were both equally talented,‚Äù Cross said.‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt tell them apart in terms of ability so it helped that they were wearing different coloured and numbered bibs so there were no problems identifying them.‚ÄúThey are only 11-years old but they are promising young players showing creative potential and it‚Äôs great to bring them into our environment.‚ÄúThey are great kids, bubbly and enthusiastic with a good attitude. They get on well with each other and their peers.‚ÄùThe boys‚Äô dad Dani could not be prouder.‚ÄúSydney FC start with Under 13‚Äôs at their academy,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúThe boys are going in a year early. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a year by year agreement that the parents sign.‚ÄúThey‚Äôve had a big advantage as twins kicking a football around the backyard from when they were tiny. They just love the game and are really excited about it.‚Äù‚ÄòROCKY‚Äô A GREAT MAN AND INNOVATORJournalism lost an all-time legend with the passing of Roy ‚ÄúRocky‚Äù Miller, a former editor of this newspaper and the most tragic St George Illawarra Dragons fan. The great man was 77.I learnt more from Rocky‚Äôs weekly Sunday Telegraph editorial meetings than I have from anyone in 46 years. He was a fanatical news chaser and innovator.Back in the 1980s, before anyone kept or thought of rugby league statistics, he sent copy boys to every game to do tackle counts. They became hugely popular in Monday‚Äôs papers.Our staff would all cheer for the Dragons each weekend knowing a victory would mean he‚Äôd be in a good mood for Tuesday morning conference. It could be miserable otherwise.As an editor, he was one of the great mentors. He gave me my start as a sports editor. I remember him playing an instrumental role in broadcaster Ray Hadley‚Äôs career in his early days. Hadley had just started the Continuous Call team on 2UE. He was up against the high-profile Hollywood and Zorba, a duo that won every footy ratings survey.Zorba used to joke: ‚ÄúRay could rob a bank without a balaclava and get away with it because no one knows who he is.‚ÄùHadley then made an appointment to meet Rocky. He needed to lift his profile and asked Miller if he could write a weekly column in The Sunday Telegraph sports section ‚Äì Hadley‚Äôs Hard Hits. He did it for free. He would soon become one of the major voices in league and regularly win the ratings.What I admired most was Rocky‚Äôs loyalty. He‚Äôd stick solid no matter what. Three weeks before his death he sent me a text about Dragons legend Craig Young, one of his all-time favourite players who was under siege as chairman for his controversial support of Brett Finch in a court reference.‚ÄúLook after him,‚Äù Rocky wrote. ‚ÄúHe made a mistake trying to help a mate (Finch‚Äôs father). Does not deserve to be crucified.‚ÄùTypical Rocky. Always looking after his beloved club ‚Ä¶ and his mates right to the end.* Rocky‚Äôs funeral is on Tuesday at 11am at St Aloysius church in Cronulla.

newsArray.content: GIOVANNI van Bronckhorst won't walk away from Rangers despite his recent struggles at Ibrox, one of his football mentors has insisted. After falling nine points behind Celtic at the top of the cinch Premiership the Rangers boss has found his job under pressure - despite an historic run to the Europa League final just six months ago. 1 Wouters worked with Rangers coaching staff Roy makaay and Arno philips under van Bronckhorst at Feyenoord. Credit: VI Images via Getty The Rangers board appears to be taking a patient approach with the Dutchman and have backed the boss so far despite the domestic slump and a horrific Champions League campaign. And one of his football mentors insists it isn't in van Bronckhorst's make up to abandon ship in stormy waters. Jam Wouters says his fellow Dutch international and former midfielder at Ibrox will stick it "because he's a fighter". The pair worked together at Feyenoord and Wouters witnessed a battling quality in the boss that makes him believe he won't quit. Wouters said: "It‚Äôs not in Gio‚Äôs character to walk away from the job, especially if there are reasons why it‚Äôs not going his way. "I know him as a person and as a coach and, no, he would never do that because he‚Äôll know that he can turn it around.‚Äù The boss is hopeful the epic injury list at Ibrox will ease off and he will be able to call upon more first-team stars after the world Cyup break. newsArray.description: FIFA President Gianni Infantino has delivered an extraordinary opening address in his press conference to welcome international media to the World Cup.
newsArray.content: In front of a packed press audience of 400 journalists in Doha‚Äôs Main Media Centre, Infantino had a lot to get off his chest given the endless list of controversies that have plagued the build up to football‚Äòs showpiece event.He was measured, calm, but held a lecture-like manner over the 55-minute opening gambit which centred mainly on criticisms of Qatar‚Äôs migrant worker population, which has constructed much of the infrastructure that will play host to the world‚Äôs best footballers, plus the issue of gay rights.Here‚Äôs part of what he had to say.OPENING REMARKS‚ÄúI‚Äôve been pretty quiet in the last few months, working behind the scenes seeing what was going on. Today, one day before the World Cup, I thought it was important to discuss the topics that have rightly or wrongly been put on the table. Some things that have been picked up in the last few months that have been quite incredible, I would say.‚ÄúToday I have very strong feelings.‚ÄúToday I feel Qatari. Today I feel Arab. Today I feel African. Today I feel gay. Today I feel disabled. Today I feel a migrant worker.‚Äù(Long pause.)‚ÄúAnd I feel this, all this, because of what I‚Äôve been seeing and what I‚Äôve been told since I don‚Äôt read, otherwise I would be depressed I think.‚ÄúWhat I see brings me back to my personal story. I am a son of migrant workers. My parents were working very, very hard in very, very difficult conditions. Not in Qatar, but in Switzerland. I remember very well, I‚Äôm not 150 years old, not speaking about apartheid in South Africa, I remember the migrant workers where they were living in Switzerland. I remember as a child how migrant workers were treated. ‚ÄúWhen I came to Doha, the first time after I was elected FIFA President, I went to see the workers‚Äô accommodation here. I was brought back to my childhood. And I say to them here this is not good. Same as Switzerland today, this has become a place of inclusion. With rights, Qatar has made progress as well.‚ÄúI feel many other things as well. Of course I am not Qatari, I am not Arab, not African, not gay, not disabled, but I feel like them, because I know what it means to be discriminated, to be bullied as a foreigner in a foreign country. I was bullied because I had red hair ‚Ä¶ and freckles.‚ÄùA TROUBLED 12 YEARS‚ÄúI feel as well, very much for all the FIFA staff. For all the Qatar Supreme Committee staff, all the volunteers., all the others. They are all here because they want to deliver to you and to the world an incredible football event. They‚Äôre all proud to be here. I‚Äôm proud to have this FIFA sign on my jacket.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not easy to read all these criticisms of the decision taken 12 years ago when nobody was there, nobody was there. And now everyone knows we have to make the best out of it. And Doha is ready, Qatar is ready, it will be the best World Cup ever, of course. The magic of football, as soon as the ball rolls, people will concentrate on that because that‚Äôs what people want.‚ÄùMIGRANT WORKERS‚ÄúWe are taught many, many lessons from Europeans and the western world. I am European. I think for Europeans what we have done in the world for the last 3000 years we should be apologising for the next 3000 years. ‚ÄúI came here six years ago and addressed the matter of migrant workers straight on, my very first meeting. How many of these western European businesses ‚Ä¶ how many have addressed migrant workers rights with the authorities? I have the answer. None of them. Because any change to the legislation means less profit. Instead of one billion profit it means 900 million profit. We did it, and FIFA generates much less than any of these companies from Qatar.‚ÄúThe country that had some pearls and sand, but what they have now is gas. If there was no gas they would not come. And now they all come. And they all want something, but who cares about the work? FIFA does, the World Cup does, and to be fair to them Qatar does as well.‚ÄùDISABLED POPULATION‚ÄúThere are one billion disabled people in the world. Nobody cares, nobody cares. 15 per cent of the world‚Äôs population is disabled. We had four journalists to an event. You think nobody suffers because nobody cares? Of course we have to care, of course we have to do things to help. Like we have to do for the workers, for the LGBT, and for any minority who is in any way suffering or being abused.‚ÄúWhilst many, many things are not perfect, change takes time. It took hundreds of years in Europe. I wonder if that‚Äôs the case. The only way of obtaining results is by engaging, searching the dialogue, not by hammering, insulting. When your child does something bad at school and you tell him you are an idiot, useless, you put him in his room, what do you think his reaction will be? ‚ÄúIf you engage with him, let‚Äôs work together and you will have better grades, he will recognise that. I don‚Äôt want to give you any lessons of life, just realising what is going on here is profoundly, profoundly unjust.‚ÄùGAY RIGHTS‚ÄúLet me also mention the LGBT situation. I have been speaking about this topic with the highest leadership in the country, several times. They have confirmed that everyone is welcome. If you have a person that says the opposite, well it‚Äôs not the opinion of the country and certainly not the opinion of FIFA. Everyone that comes is welcome. Whatever religion, race, sexual orientation, belief she or he has, everyone is welcome. ‚ÄúThe Qatari state sticks to that requirement. They will tell you that legislation that prohibits that to jail. Yes, these legislations exist in many countries in the world. These legislations existed during the World Cup in Switzerland in 1954. So again, like the workers, these are processes.‚Äù‚ÄúWhat do you want to do about it? You want to stay home and hammer, and criticise these Arabs or these Muslims because it‚Äôs not allowed in public? Of course I believe it should be allowed as FIFA President. If I ask the same question to my father if he‚Äôs not here anymore, he probably has a different answer to me. So if somebody thinks by just hammering and criticising you will achieve something, well I can tell you, you will achieve exactly the opposite. And that‚Äôs bad.‚ÄùFAKE FANS‚ÄúThe world is divided enough. We are organising the World Cup. We are not organising a war. We are organising a World Cup, that many people have many problems in their life, for them to come and enjoy. To go see the teams, be happy. Cheer the teams. ‚ÄúAnd what do I read? Well they don‚Äôt look like English, they look like Indians, they shouldn‚Äôt cheer for English. Can someone who does look like they are from England go cheer for them, or for Spain, or for Germany? You know what this is. This is racism. This is pure racism. We need to stop it. Because everyone in the world has the right to cheer for who he or she wants. Tolerance starts with ourselves, we shouldn‚Äôt spread aggression. We should spread understanding.‚ÄùFIFA‚ÄôS ROLE IN THE WORLD‚ÄúFootball brings people together. If we want to organise an event in North Korea, I actually went to North Korea some years ago to ask if they were ready to host part of a Women‚Äôs World Cup with South Korea. I was not successful, obviously, but I will go another hundred times if it would help. Only engagement can bring real change.‚ÄúI‚Äôm still convinced ‚Ä¶ this particular World Cup will help to open the eyes of the world.‚ÄùSTADIUM BEER BAN‚ÄúHonestly, if this is the biggest issue we have for the World Cup I will sign up immediately to go to the beach and relax until the 18th of December. Every decision that is taken in this World Cup is a joint decision. Between Qatar and FIFA. It is discussed and taken jointly. There will be many 8-10 fan zones, and over 200 places you can buy alcohol in Qatar. The late change of policy is because we tried until the end to see what was possible.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Celtic ace Daizen Maeda opens up on World Cup bid, his disappointment for team-mates Reo Hatate and Kyogo‚Ä¶ and BAKING!
creator: David Friel
newsArray.content: DAIZEN MAEDA admits he once behaved like a bit of a doughball during his high school days. But a year-long ban from football and a part-time job in a BAKERY set him on the path to the World Cup with Japan. 3 Daizen Maeda has been training without his Celtic mates in the Japan camp at Doha. Credit: PHILIP FONG/AFP via Getty Images 3 Maeda has been assigned the penultimate squad number in the Blue Samurai squad. Maeda, 25, was a promising teenager when indiscipline saw him expelled from the prestigious Yamanashi Gakuin University‚Äôs high school team for 12 months. The Celtic star admits the penny dropped as he trained alone in the mountains and took on a job making curry bread in a local shop. Coach Kazuaki Yoshinaga‚Äôs hardline stance taught Maeda a valuable lesson and the Hoops striker reckons it was the making of him. He said: ‚ÄúIf it wasn‚Äôt for that one year, I don‚Äôt think I would be playing football like this now. Until then, I was doing naughty things, and I really only thought about myself on and off the pitch. Read More Scottish Football Boss blast Rangers crisis is NOTHING like this - Dodds calls out SPFL with 10 out injured SUNSPORT PREDICTIONS Who will be World Cup winners, ones to watch & top SPFL performer ‚ÄúIn that year, I learned I can‚Äôt do anything on my own, and I can play with the support of many people, and the importance of running for the team. It all connected. ‚ÄúWhen I was expelled from the team, I didn‚Äôt know if I would be able to return at any time. I loved football and I didn‚Äôt want to quit football, and if I transferred schools it would be like going giving up. ‚ÄúI stayed and trained alone. There was a mountain near my school and I would run there, and also around the field. ‚ÄúThere was an adult team in the area and I was eventually allowed to train with them, so I was grateful. Most read in Football GOOD AS GOLD Gers hero in Connor Goldson injury return hint - but another star not so lucky BIG CALL Celtic have got away with 'interesting' VAR decisions, says Rangers hero Souness NEVER STOP Celtic boss Postecoglou WON'T slow down as nine-day Hoops break plan revealed PART TIME REF Willie Collum at centre of bizarre world first as referee granted huge honour ‚ÄúAround that time, I started working part-time at a local bakery in the mornings. Before going to school, I used to wake up at 5am and ride my bike to get there at 5.30. "I would fry curry bread but sometimes I would make holes when turning it over with chopsticks ‚Äî I really made many mistakes! ‚ÄúAfter a year, I was told that I could return to the football team from scratch. There was another classmate who was expelled with me, so for a while we worked on various things and gradually joined the general training. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt forgotten that period and how everyone worked to help me, including the people at the bakery. It was very important for me.‚Äù Maeda‚Äôs career has been on the rise ever since and he is now in contention to start Japan‚Äôs World Cup opener with Germany on Wednesday. 3 Daizen Maeda hasn't forgotten his baking roots before being given a second-chance at football. Credit: The Asahi Shimbun via Getty Images He wishes that his Celtic pals Reo H atate and Kyogo Furuhashi were with him but he wants to do the nation proud in Qatar. He said: ‚ÄúYes, I feel sorry for them both. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame they are not going to the World Cup but I will do my best on behalf of them in Qatar. ‚ÄúI think we have a chance. The first game that we have against Germany will be very important. ‚ÄúWe are targeting victory in that match and hopefully that will put us in a good rhythm. ‚ÄúCeltic and the national team have very different playing styles so I need to adjust my game. ‚ÄúIt puts different demands on me mentally and physically but I need to adapt to play well. ‚ÄúMy full focus is on Japan. Once I finish international duty my focus will return to Celtic. ‚ÄúHopefully I will still have plenty of energy for the games when I come back but I am not thinking about that too much at the moment.‚Äù Maeda is one of four Celtic players at the Qatar finals and he hopes Aaron Mooy, Cameron Carter-Vickers and Josip Juranovic have success with their countries. He said: ‚ÄúWe are all in different groups so I think we will be wanting each other to do well. newsArray.description: Samoan coach Matt Parish has branded referee Ashley Klein‚Äôs decision to send Kangaroos backrower Angus Crichton to the sin bin as ‚Äúweak‚Äù.
newsArray.content: The 26-year-old raised his elbow while bracing for a tackle from Samoa‚Äôs dummy-half Chanel Harris-Tavita in the 46th minute, who was knocked out by the contact.Watch Australia v Samoa in the Rugby League World Cup Final this Sunday. Plus catch up on all the action with Kayo Minis. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now >The ugly blow saw Fox League‚Äôs commentators tipping Crichton to be sent off, but Klein instead raised 10 fingers and gave the backrower his marching orders.‚ÄúThis could be the end of Crichton‚Äôs night Vossy,‚Äù the commentator said.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a dead ball situation and the elbow is raised, it looks worse the more you slow it down, but for all intents and purposes there is head contact when the ball is dead,‚Äù Fox League‚Äôs Andrew Voss said.‚ÄúThis is a big moment.‚Äù‚ÄúI think Crichton might be lucky to stay on the field, whatever card this may be,‚Äù the commentator said.Parish‚Äôs side went down 30-10 and were valiant against Mal Meninga‚Äôs Kangaroos, but the Samoan coach was clearly angry they weren‚Äôt playing against 12 players for almost a full half.‚ÄúFive minutes into the second half our hooker gets elbowed in the head and gets carted off, then the referee makes a weak decision and puts him in the bin, dumbfounded,‚Äù Parish said.‚ÄúAn elbow to the head and the hooker gets knocked out and taken out of the game.‚ÄùAustralian coach Mal Meninga though disagreed, telling reporters: ‚ÄúMy view is that he should have stayed on the field, that‚Äôs just silly‚Äù.The Samoan squad was down to bare bones after a number of injuries forced players to sit out of the tournament.Parish revealed he only had a squad of 19 players to pick from coming into the World Cup final.Hamiso Tabuai-Fidow, Tyrone May, Braden Hamlin-Uele, Josh Aloiai, Izack Tago and Fa‚Äôamanu Brown all sat out of the clash, while Spencer Leniu played but was in doubt in the days prior to the game.Hooker Danny Levi also returned home due to personal reasons.‚ÄúDown to 19 players, that‚Äôs all we had in the squad, blokes playing out of position, blokes playing full halves and it was so courageous,‚Äù Parish said.Samoan skipper Junior Paulo went in to bat for Crichton, who he has played with before in the NSW Blues set-up under Brad Fittler.‚ÄúKnowing Angus Crichton and playing with him before, it‚Äôs probably not in his game so it is what it is,‚Äù Paulo said.Meanwhile, Harris-Tavita dropped a bombshell on the rugby league world earlier this year by announcing he‚Äôd be taking an indefinite break from the game following the World Cup.The 23-year-old slotted into hooker after Samoa‚Äôs injury crisis and was desperate for a dream way to exit the game for the time being.Unfortunately he left the field after suffering the ugly head knock and was unable to return.‚ÄúThis is the bad luck that has cursed Samoa through the tournament,‚Äù Voss said.‚ÄúHarris-Tavita, this could be his last moment in rugby league what we have just witnessed there.‚ÄùSpeaking post-match Crichton also revealed he will be travelling with Harris-Tavitain the weeks following the World Cup.‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know he was coming and there was no malice at all, sending out my blessings to his family,‚Äù Crichton said.‚ÄúIt is all love between me and Chanel, I spoke to him after the game and I apologised, whenever I play football I don‚Äôt try to injury anyone.‚ÄúI never want to see anyone get injured on a football field, we love rugby league because of the nature of the sport, we don‚Äôt go out there trying to hurt people.‚ÄúI just want everyone to know it was just a genuine reaction, I never go out on the field to try and hurt someone.‚ÄúHe's a great player and I am actually meant to be travelling with him after this so there‚Äôs no bad blood between me and Chanel.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs great friends with Nathan Cleary, who I am also great mates with... I am genuinely sorry for that, it was not my intention at all.‚ÄùHarris-Tavita revealed he came to the decision to walk away from the game after getting injured during a heavy loss to the Storm in Round 7 of the 2022 season.‚ÄúFor the past couple of years I just haven‚Äôt felt that love for the game, I‚Äôve woken up on many training days and asked myself - is this really what I want to do,‚Äù Harris-Tavita said.‚ÄúIt was hard for me to make this decision because you can get a lot of money in this game and you have a short career, so that was one of the toughest parts.‚ÄúBut after I‚Äôd ruptured my testicle, I spent a bit of time by myself contemplating my next move and (whether to) sign my next contract, and the decision I made was the best for me moving forward.‚Äù
